Your Land is not Advertise for Sale that I Know of I Said to Your friend that Thomas? at Oxford & found the land returned delinquent that as land with Taxes not Paid & the Taxes were so high I did not Pay them I think they were about $2100 but presume ere this you have Recd a line from Oxford Sat? You all right we are having a considerable cholera here now & most all fatall I hope for my Young family Sake we may Escape it if I Should be taken away it is my wish that Brother David together with my Wife Should Settle up my affairs he is Young & Healthy & Honest Would leave then with You but Your health is not as promising as his. I have not lost About $1400 since new years beside the loss of the General use of my hand & find myself Surrounded by a large family of little children which must have a vast amt of constance Care & Situated as I now am it is impossible for me to give them much of my time. I Bot in June that forty acres lying in the forks of the ? Where You and I got out of the buggy  & Gave $200 for it (I lost About $400 on Pork) Why does not David Write me if I could see him I Should find fault with for it,  let me hear from You & David for I feel anxious to hear from You often Er____

Your Brother 
E.N. Kendall

La Fayette Oct 4th 1855
Brother Nathan

                               I have been in La Fayette the past ten Day & I have Brot my family With me Situated as I am do not see how I can possibly get up my house this fall & to Keep my family out there this Winter. I do not think it Would be right. We feel as though perhaps we might have had Eddy with us if we had remained in Town untill we had got our house up. When I think of it Seems almost Awful to think I can never more see him in this world again. I have never had any thing in this life to affect me so the poor Boy so hard for us to take him to Town & we did not. I  am going to all I can to get my home safe as soon as possible & all You can help me will be safe & if You should need it. When I have not got it I would sell my team to raise it the some?   Hundred Dollars. You said I could have. I need very much & You can send it by Pony Express co. or send me a draft Write me in future at La Fayette & please write as often as You feel like it for it Give Me much pleasure to hear from You. We have nearly all of as had the ague but are now getting Better

Your Brother
Erasmus N Kendall

La Fayette Oct 20/1855
Dear Brother Nathan

                                             Yours Was Rec'd in My Absence the Two Hundred Dolls came by Express all night & Enclosed You find my note for same which I will pay You ten per cent interest. I have been in the country for the Last ten Day Cutting up corn & am now agoing to Try and put up my house & Stable & if you can help me You will do me a favour & You money will be sure When You need it I would like to see You & also if I had time Write You a long letter. I feel almost as though I should fly about Eddy & Where Ever I find myself. I am dissatisfied & Lonesome anything You Wish to Send by Express will come no Doubt Safe

Your Affectionate Brother

   I presume You Wonder about receiving letters from me but Evry moment almost I am busy since I wrote You I have built me a Small barn 26 feet Wide 32 feet long have had my corn to cut up feed lot to make money to collect & thousand almost of other things to attend to I have 50 odd head of cattle wintering & co the man that built the barn will Build the house but do not know as I Shall be Able to furnish him money to do so he wants me to let him Know the next time I go out  now Can you help me any if You can I will Try & do as much for You if You have any money You can spare now I should like it much -  I find I have to much on my hands more than I can well attend to and in order to be comfortable Shall be obliged to rent my farm some way the Coming Year. La Fayette Jan 7th 1857
Dear Brother Nathan

                             Yours was Rec'd Yesterday at the time of it arrived I was at the farm and so to the time I Expect they use us all hard.. I have been in tight places all the fall.. But notwithstanding the time if I could have been situated so as to have managed my own Business Both on farm in Store & making collection outside the times would not have been felt by me as they are now. I owe some three thousand dollars But have plenty to pay with in Shape of Personal property or Good notes But find they are not many But am not affraid But I Shall worrie though. After, a Sort I have 42 Head of five Cattle 10 Head of Horses Rest Hogs Wheat Barley & co. Shall have 4000 Bushel Prime corn beside Enough to Winter my Sock & six or seven thousand Dolls of notes & of @ which if I could collect one half or more My Stock in Sore is Some Twelve or fourteen Hundred Dollars.. As for Yourself I have been Sorry Ever since I heard You were connected with the Sawmill You could not have

Kept out of it. I consider from hearsay that Sawmill Business is a very risky Business. At all Events Situated as You are I hope You will place Your land in Benton & White @ In a I hope so?You will not lose them they an be saved if not put of to late. So You can get there again as for David going to Grocerie Business it will Depend upon him self & Connecting Circumstances the profit are Small But turns are Quick but he has not any Experience in it and consequently will be apt to credit men he think are his friends & they will Disappoint him but if he can do Business Enough without credit to justify him he will I own learn groceries are Bot on very shorttime provisions will be cash all the time as far as Dollars & cents are concerned he could make more money to take on Half of my Business.. But I do not suppose it would suit him; As for capitoll A man can commence on very little if he managed every thing connected with him accordingly = I Shall be glad to See You and talk with You I feel Bad to think I have not Situated my family up town so as to be able to Entertain my friends When they call on me & have promised there to do so in the Spring  I have a good house on the farm But cannot move on it for Year or Two Yet although we are as comfortable ourselves living over the store as anywhere. Please put off Bringing Your family untill we can get moved in Spring uptown Yours most 
Affectionately
ENKendall

Phillipston April 26 1846
Dear Son  I received your letter and was very glad to hear frome you and Lydia and have delayed answering it untill now, thinking I should receive one from Sarah Jane or Raymond as I wrote them and requested an answer soon but it seems they have something dearer than mother or home to take their minds or they would have written before now. I received a letter from Erasmus dat. April 13 said he had another son 2 weeks old was well and Sarah had a good nurse was getting along well he called his name Thomas Marshall for his little brother. Nathan I am glad he respects his brother enough to call it for him for the name is very dear to me, my past trials weigh heavy upon me I know it is the will of God and hope I feel resigned to his will. I try to overcome my feelings as much as I can but they will come daily before me. I am very  -  pleasantly situated my health has been very good except my head which has troubled me for the past two weeks very much I think. I must try and go out among my friends and and see if I cannot wean? it away. Myron is well has been and stayed to his Aunt Cutting 1 week. I stayed 3 days went home with Rebekah and stayed 4 days and helped her fix her things to go to Townsend the 2d week in April. Her father convinced her, and found Blake sick at Titchburge and brought hm and his wife home. I think August, will have enough to do as Sophia is going to teach No. 5 this summer she wanted I should stay with her, but I told her I thought

I should go to Albany, for I thought it would not be very profitable to go their to work. Erasmus said he had not concluded to stay with his employers should not if they did not give him 50 dollars a year more should know the first of May and then would write and let me know, wanted I should come and make them a visit this summer if he stayed at Albany  - wanted to know where you and Raymond was so that he could write you. David is at work at Mr. Richardson's for 40 dol a year & have not heard from Jesse since you was there. Betsey J. Fry is published and I do not know but married to Mr. Cheney. Should like to know what you think about my going out to see Erasmus when Lydia comes home.  I think I can get a place for Myron while I am gone. Daniel Perkins is in town studying with his brothers, nothing more untill I see you.
From your mother Jane Kendall
Nathan Kendall

Phillipston May 9th 1847
Dear Son

                  Not having received a letter from you to let us know where you was, and being under the necessity of writing to you for Jesse, I shall direct my letter to Townshend Vt. Jesse came home to me last friday Mr. Bragg having sent him after breakfast to turn the cows out and go to work, he took a direct course across to Mr. Richardsons and then home got home about noon without any outside jacket with his old clothes. he said he had stayed expecting every year to leave but found it of no use I ask him if Mr. Bragg had misused him he said he had not, but there was a boy last week told him Mr. B said he only kept him to accommodate you; and then he went to ? hill the day before and he had a great many stories told him, he said he promised not to tell who told and we could not persuade him to tell, I expect he was influenced to come away. David came home that night and Edwin also, David said he told him, if he wanted to to come home he should changed his clothes & told Mr. B where he was a going and Edwin has the same but now they know not what to do for we thought Mr. Bragg's people must feel very bad not knowing where he was. Edwin conducted to go with him saturday night and see Mr. B and get his clothes if they would let them come. Edwin thought he had done very wrong. I think the boy did not consider the step he was taking. Mr. Bragg came to our house saturday forenoon felt very much grieved to think he should leave in that manner did not know he was discontented said if he had changed his clothes and let them know he was coming he should

not hindered him, he thinks he was told what to do the day before or he never would have done, it was well persuaded who it was he came home to dinner sent his boy to call Jesse, could not find him he went himself hunted the pastures and concluded he would go to the railroad they said he first was? there so he went home and come the next morning he says the stories are all false he never has changed a word with any one but his father about his staying wanted Jesse should go back and stay if he could be contented offered him some priveleges if he would go back but we could not persuade him on any other way than this. I should write to you and have you instruct Edwin what to do and he Edwin would go up fortnight from saturday if he was not contented etch him home. Mr. Bragg wanted he should go home with him if he must leave go as he had ought for it was not only giving the boy a bad name but hi also, feels very bad not to have him tell who should tell such stories, thinks he will be contented when he gets back, if he is not we do not any of us wish him to stay for it may caus him to be unsteady and do worse it has caused many a Tear from all of us, wish you to write Mr. Bragg a pleasant letter for it has caused him trouble if the boy is contented let him stay if not let Edwin get him a good place if you think best. please write as soon as you receive this. Myron has gotte to be quite well excepting his strength which is week. Sarah is going to stay at L. this summer and fall; I received a letter from PK he says he shall be at home the middle of July has been sick with the lung fever wanted to know when you was why you did not come there Lydia went home with M B & Jesse my health is as good as when we left

Delioo Ann Bunton died the next week after you left home. Jane Smith & Charles Baldwin are published. I have been to meeting to day had 2 good sermons from 2 Timothy 2 chpt 19 verse by Mr. Bullard of Titchburgh wish you could have herd them, hope you will make a wise improvement of all the sermons you hear pray that you may be rightly instructed  when you read the scriptures is the wish of your mother. Lydia goes to Petersham next week Sarah Cheney begins No. 7 tomorrow Nancy Baker teaches No.1 the people were very much disappointed not getting Sarah. I was also, but think it best for her to stay where she is, must say I do not feel pleased with her religious society she attends; you will think I am wrong. I feel I have done wrong I have not talked with them my family more than I have may I be enabled to do my duty more faithfull.
from your Affectionate mother
Jane Kendall

Provincetown June 4th 1848
Dear Son

                           Having a sincere wish to hear from all my children I address a few lines to you wishing you would not neglect to answer it as soon as received. My health has improved and is still improving  my friends want I should stay untill Sept. I think it is doubtful about my staying for there has been several cases of smallpox, as I never was vaccinated for the kine? pose I think I shall be the coming week. I have found many very pleasant friends in this place and those that move in the first circle in society. I am going down to Mary Dyers Tuesday at the lower end of the town think of spending the week among my friends their. Remember me to your Grandfather tell him I have been to see Aunt Elizabeth found her comfortable and all the rest of his friends well excepting Susan Convert she is most gone with consumption. I spent the day with her yesterday, the Universalist have built them a new meeting house and sold their old one to the Methodist which are repairing it and hired another --- Methodist preacher so that they have two methodist societies. I think they have a good speaker in this orthodox house you hear a great stir about meetings in this place. Give my love to all my children and all my friends if any I have who

inquire after me in particular to Jesse tell him to know not how often he is in his mother's mind she wants he should be a good boy not neglect his bible and meeting. Tell Myron if you see him I daily think of that little son who waited on me the past winter. God has said he will be a Father to the fatherly and those that seek him early shall find him may that be the blessing of my children. I received a letter from Sarah she said you was at home. I wish you all could just step down and see Provincetown it would be very pleasant to view the harbour and on high hill you could see all the back of the cape. I think you would not any one of you be willing to live here. wish you would write how your brothers get along with their farm a how Sarah is whether her work is to hard? for her, A kiss to Edgar & Marshall do write soon. I shall write to David in the course of next week have wrote to Lydia by this mail. Jesse Kendall has gone to the bay fishing his child died the first week I came here he did not know of its death when he went away.

       from your Affectionate mother
                      Jane Kendall

Phillipston Jan, 19=1857
My ever dear Son

                                  I now seat myself to answer you letter of your, 4= which was received with much pleasure hearing your health was so good as it is, health is a great blessing to all who have it, my health has been comfortably good this winter. Lydia was taken with the throat distemper and rash the second saturday after she began her school was so that she could not get home was quite sick for 2 weeks, is in school now but does not step on the snow is very lame; most part of the time her limbs are swolen very much and are very painful. I have heard from her yesterday she was not able to teach last Wednesday but has taught since then, think she will be quite low spirited if she is not better. Your Uncle N Bragg died last sunday he was taken friday with a fit of the palsy died. S. Stilman _ Smith died last Sunday bleeding at the lungs he worked friday, has been out of health for some months. Royalston meeting house was burnt last Tuesday might with Ms. Bullock's house and some other buildings think they was set on fire. They are about sending for a charter for a railroad from Salem depot to Winchester town Vt? to intersect at NY line with Cheshire, several men have been

engaged two days looking the route it progress through below your Uncle Cheney's by Geo.? Baker's so down that stream. I hope Phillipston will have something to build it up. We are to have a donation party at Mr. Perkin's, next Tuesday evening for the grown people & Wednesday afternoon for the children under fountain. Myron think much of going hope they will all enjoy themselves. I received a letter from Sarah yesterday she writes with better spirits say her health is much better than it was at K, which I was glad to hear, have not heard from Erasmus since last fall wish if you hear from him you would write me for you do not know how much I think of him and want to see him and his family. Had a letter from David few weeks since he and Edwin was well. I am going to write to Edwin to day was very glad to hear Jesse is doing better. I write to him and advise him. I tell him how he ought to do to get along. Myron is going to write for himself. You asked if I should want any money this spring. I know not how the rent is to be paid but trust we shall find a way when it becomes due. It is hard for me to have to depend on my children for it, think sometimes if Myron can get a place I will not keep house but then my children want a home if it is ?, we have enjoyed our home the past year and hope we shall the year to come. Cousin Jesse has been up from the cape he is going whaleing the coming season. Please give my love to you write soon, From your affectionate Mother
Jane Kendall

Phillipston Jan 19th 1851

                   Dear Brother
                                         As Mother has left a page I thought that I would write a few lines to let you know how I am getting along. am going to school this winter have Mr. E.S. Fish for teacher  study Arithmetic and Grammar have got to the ? page in Arithmetic, we have had good sleighing  ever since it began on the 7th of Dec. I have been traping this winter have had pretty good luck have catched 3 Rabbits 1 flying squirrel  & red ones and lost one of them. Foxes were very thick around here a hound chased one by here the other day. I expect we shall have rail roads all around nextnews they think of having one through this town. Washington Baker is married to Miss. Harriet Seaduke. I don't think of any more to write now pleas write soon

your affectionate Brother
